page.title: 14Welsh language in Flint
page.content: Since the days of Edward the first, Flint has been{linguistically an {English town-}the Welsh poet Lewis Glyn Cothi writing "Dychan Saeson Fflint". A few{Welsh names}survive, like{Croes Ati and Allt Goch,}as well as the{tradition of Codi Ha',}an ancient May Day celebration where people black their faces and dress in white clothes. The visit of the {National Eisteddfod to Flint in 1969 helped to create a feeling of Welshness. Today many road signs are {bilingual,}as well as signs in Boots chemist. The male voice choir sing in Welsh and Caersalem and Peniel chapels hold services in Welsh.{Ysgol Heol {Gaer}is shortly to become a{Welsh {medium school.}At present it has a Welsh and English section and is unusual because over 90% of the pupils come from English speaking homes.
